PERSONAL HEALTH: FORGET THE SUNTAN 

  (ART ADV: Photo NYT 15 is being sent to NYT photo clients.
Nonsubscribers can purchase one-time rights by calling 888-603-1036
or 888-346-9867.) 
 (The Science Times)  
 By JANE E. BRODY    
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service    

   John McCain's unfortunate return bout with melanoma should serve
as a wake-up call for the millions of Americans _ especially young
Americans _ who still worship the sun, skimp on sunscreen and bare
their skin to UV radiation to just within the limits of decency.

   It should also remind everyone of the importance of
self-vigilance. Since no one knows your skin and its many markings
better than you, you have primary responsibility for checking often
for any changes that could herald skin cancer.

   Melanoma is the most serious form of skin cancer, with the
capacity to spread and ultimately kill. It can recur years after
treatment of a first melanoma, and, as seems to have happened to
McCain, new melanomas can develop at any time after an original
melanoma is seemingly cured.

   Now in the United States, the incidence of melanoma is rising at
an exponential rate: 4 percent a year for 20 years, accompanied by
an increase of nearly 2 percent a year in melanoma deaths. One
person in 74 can now expect to develop melanoma at some point, up
from one in 1,500 in 1935 and one in 250 two decades ago.

   This year, doctors are expected to diagnosis invasive malignant
melanoma in 47,700 people and melanoma still in an early
noninvasive stage in up to 40,000 people. Melanoma will kill an
estimated 7,700 people in this country this year, many of them in
the prime of life.

   You see, melanoma is a cancer that afflicts the young and old. A
quarter of new cases now occur in people younger than 40, and half
of all cases occur in people younger than 54.

   Melanoma is the leading cancer in women in their late 20s and
second only to breast cancer among women in their early 30s. In
terms of years of life lost to cancer, melanoma ranks second only
to adult leukemia.

   Have I scared you into action? I hope so. Let's start with what
we know about preventing this disease. Melanomas can sometimes
occur on parts of the body like the soles of the feet and palms of
the hands, that are not routinely exposed to the sun. But 95
percent of cases occur on sun-exposed parts of the body, especially
the head and neck, upper back and, particularly in women, the legs.
Back in the days of long skirts, women rarely, if ever, got
melanoma on their legs.

   Certain circumstances can render a person especially susceptible
to melanoma. These include having suffered three or more blistering
sunburns before age 20, repeated exposure to UV light in a tanning
salon, having worked three or more summers as a teen-ager at an
outdoor job, having many moles that change in appearance, prior
treatment with psoralen and UV light for psoriasis and a history of
melanoma in a parent or sibling.

   Fair-skinned people, especially those with blond or red hair,
blue or green eyes, lots of freckles on the upper back and an
inability to tan, are also at much greater than average risk of
developing melanoma (as well as superficial skin cancers).

   People who have had several precancers of the skin (actinic
keratoses) are also at greater than average risk. Having three or
more of the above factors raises a person's risk of developing
melanoma 30-fold.

   Bursts of sun exposure seem to be more of a problem than
continuous sun. People with outdoor jobs are less likely to develop
melanoma than indoor workers who experience intense sun exposure on
their days off.

   You may have heard a report that sunscreens do not protect
against melanoma. That is not entirely true. In Australia and
Hawaii, where three-quarters or more of the people now regularly
use sunscreen, the melanoma rate has begun to fall.

   But until two years ago, most sunscreens contained agents that
reduced the risk of sunburn from ultraviolet-B rays, which allowed
people to stay in the sun and remain exposed to skin-damaging
ultraviolet-A rays far longer than they otherwise might have.

   The SPF (sun protection factor) rating of sunscreens refers only
to a product's ability protect against sunburn, and most people
apply too little sunscreen too infrequently to glean anything like
the level of protection stated on the package. Toss out the old
products and replace them with a new sunscreen that offers both
UV-A and UV-B protection; these contain either Parsol 1789 or
micronized zinc or titanium oxide.

   Anyway, sunscreen is considered a secondary measure to be relied
upon when sun exposure cannot be avoided, for example, while
swimming or playing tennis. Primary protection against sun damage
comes from staying out of the sun, especially at midday and wearing
protective clothing for prolonged exposure.

   I have invested in three shirts that have sun-blocking
properties even when wet. They are not cheap _ about $60 or $70
each _ but I consider them an insurance policy. I wear them while
hiking, kayaking and snorkeling. Also available are sun-protective
hats, pants and skirts.

   When melanoma is detected and treated in its early stages, the
cure rate approaches 100 percent (although this is no guarantee
that new melanomas won't develop later on). In more advanced
stages, the fatality rate exceeds 70 percent. Regular full-body
examinations for signs of trouble are important for everyone, since
most melanomas occur in people not considered at high risk.

   Self-examination for suspicious skin lesions starts with
stripping to the buff. Then stand in a well-lighted room in front
of a full-length mirror, using a hand mirror to facilitate views of
your sides, underarms, back and buttocks. Don't forget to check
your scalp, toes and soles of your feet. If you lack a long mirror
or for other reasons cannot do a complete exam on your own, ask for
help from a spouse, significant other or good friend.

   What are you looking for? First, any lesion _ pigmented or not _
that seems to have changed in size or shape since your last
self-exam. Hallmarks of an early, curable melanoma follow an
``ABCD'' guideline: A for an asymmetrical appearance, B for an
irregular border, C for color variations of black and light and
dark brown (or even pink, red, white or blue) and D for a diameter
greater than a quarter of an inch. Some experts now add an E for
enlargement, that is, a mole that is growing in height or width.
Look, too, for any change in the surface or texture of a mole and
for changes in sensation, like itching, tenderness or pain.

   Self-exams for possible skin cancer should be done monthly, and
at the very least, every three months. If you see your doctor once
a year, have the doctor perform a full-body check as well. Report
any suspicious lesion you find to your physician, preferably to a
dermatologist who specializes in skin cancer. And if your doctor
refers you to a specialist for a more detailed exam or biopsy, act
promptly; delaying treatment can result in a more serious and less
curable cancer, if that is what you have.

   You may also consult an excellent book on melanoma and other
skin cancers, ``Saving Your Skin'' by Dr. Barney Kenet and Patricia
Lawler, published in 1994.
